<p><strong>The need to make sustained and serious progress</strong> toward ethnic and racial justice is clearin the United Kingdom and elsewhere. COVID-19 has <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-in-the-united-kingdom-assessing-jobs-at-risk-and-the-impact-on-people-and-places">disproportionately affected Britains</a> ethnic minorities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b21c429e-0c55-4ae7-b151-96df82a3dce0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b21c429e-0c55-4ae7-b151-96df82a3dce0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In general, we report our results based on terms used by the Office for National Statistics, which typically classifies individuals as follows: Bangladeshi, Black, Chinese, Indian, mixed ethnicity, other Asian, other ethnicity, Pakistani, and white. In some statistics, further breakdowns are available. The other Asian group comprises people from the region who are not Bangladeshi, Chinese, Indian, or Pakistani. The mixed ethnicity group comprises individuals who report having multiple ethnic backgrounds; the largest subgroup is Black/white. The other ethnicity group comprises people not included in any of the other categories, with people of Middle Eastern descent representing around 40 percent of the total. Due to sample sizes and reporting conventions, not all data sources provide the same breakdown. In those cases, we explain the alternative breakdowns used in footnotes. Data also differ in geographic coverage. We report results even if data are available only for England or for England and another UK region.</span></span></span></a></span> In the longer term, globalization and automation could <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/inequality-a-persisting-challenge-and-its-implications">worsen inequality</a>.</p>
<p>What to do depends on the specific circumstances of each country. Our colleagues <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/us-hispanic-and-latino-lives-and-livelihoods-in-the-recovery-from-covid-19">in the United States</a> have published a <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-advancing-asian-american-recovery">series of analyses on specific ethnic groups</a>. In this report, we look at the United Kingdom, where about one in seven people, or 14 percent, belong to a minority ethnic group (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9a1a18f1-e97e-4106-9a65-20fda61ea0ee"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9a1a18f1-e97e-4106-9a65-20fda61ea0ee" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">According to the 2011 census for England and Wales; the percentages are not appreciably different for the United Kingdom, which also includes Scotland and Northern Ireland. In addition, 2016 estimates show similar figures. Population estimates by ethnic group, in <em>Research report on population estimates by ethnic group and religion,</em> Office for National Statistics, updated December 4, 2019, ons.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Those figures are likely to change, however. Ethnic minorities are younger than average, accounting for 20 percent of those aged 24 or under; by 2051, they could account for one in five of the population. The implication is that ethnic minorities will become even more important in terms of their contribution to society and the economy than they are now. Already, they account for more than 300 billion in purchasing power,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a908b138-4f28-4c4c-9000-f4002ccd2081"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a908b138-4f28-4c4c-9000-f4002ccd2081" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>2012 Multicultural Britain,</em> Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, 2012, ipa.co.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> and ethnic-minority-owned small businesses contribute 25 billion a yearor as much as the chemical industryto the countrys gross value added.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="11b79b49-fbc5-4e2b-a17f-b71335616e69"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="11b79b49-fbc5-4e2b-a17f-b71335616e69" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">National Federation of Self-Employed & Small Businesses, July 2020, fsb.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Highlights of the research</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Ethnic-minority individuals</strong> make up 14 percent of the overall population in the United Kingdom, and 20 percent of those aged 24 and below.</p>
<p>Among state-school pupils aged 18, people from all ethnic-minority groups were more likely to enter higher education than white students.</p>
<p>From 2004 to 2018, the labor-force participation gap of ethnic-minority workers relative to white workers shrank by three percentage points, to 9.5 percent.</p>
<p>Ethnic-minority women account for 76 percent of the labor-force participation gap. Ethnic-minority women aged 16 to 24 account for 21 percent of the gap but only 11 percent of the labor force.</p>
<p>When comparing employees of similar age, qualifications, occupation, and sector, ethnic-minority workers earned 10 percent less than white workers.</p>
<p>More than 15 percent of Bangladeshi and Chinese employees were in sectors that furloughed 70 percent of workers in the second quarter of 2020, compared with 8 percent of white workers, 7 percent of Black workers, 6 percent of Pakistanis, and 5 percent of Indians.</p>
<p>More than 25 percent of Bangladeshis and Pakistanis work in occupations whose automation potential is more than 60 percent, compared with 17 percent of white and Black workers, and 16 percent of Chinese and Indian workers.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The focus of our analysis is on the socioeconomic aspects of ethnic equality, looking at the position of Britains Black, Asian, and minority ethnic (BAME) groups in terms of employment, earnings, education, health, and well-being (see sidebar, Highlights of the research). The circumstances for different groups can vary significantly, so we also draw out findings on specific minorities throughout the report.</p>
<p>Overall, there are five major findings. First, over the past two decades, every British ethnic-minority group has made progress, in both absolute terms and relative to the white majority, in labor-force participation, employment, occupational mix, and education. Second, despite the progress, ethnic minorities still do less well than white people in most socioeconomic areas. (The exception is education, where minorities generally do better.) Third, there are large differences between specific groups. People of Chinese and Indian origin tend to do well on all measures studied, and often better than white people; the metrics for Bangladeshis, Black people, and Pakistanis are usually worse.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="55982bba-45f3-47b4-8331-afd4d98b492e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="55982bba-45f3-47b4-8331-afd4d98b492e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For the sake of simplicity, in this report, we use terms like Bangladeshi, Chinese, Indian, and Pakistani. The great majority of these individuals are British citizens, and we do not mean to imply otherwise.</span></span></span></a></span> Fourth, global shocksincluding the coronavirus pandemic and large-scale automationare not helping. Not only do all ethnic-minority groups have higher age-adjusted COVID-19 death rates than white people, but Bangladeshis and Pakistanis in particular are concentrated in occupations that have been hard hit by furloughs and layoffs. They also appear to be more vulnerable than other ethnicities to job losses associated with automation. And finally, our analysis points to clear priorities for communities, employers, and government at all levels.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Britains ethnic minorities account for more than 300 billion in purchasing power, and minority-owned small businesses contribute 25 billion a year to the countrys gross value added.</p></blockquote></div>
<h2>How Britains ethnic minorities are faring in the labor market</h2>
<p>How are Britains ethnic minorities doing in labor-force participation, employment, occupational mix, and pay? Its complicated.</p>
<h3>What is the labor-force participation and unemployment profile for ethnic minorities?</h3>
<p>In 2018, all ethnic-minority groups had lower labor-force participation ratesdefined as the percentage of 16- to 64-year-olds who were working or looking for workthan their white counterparts (Exhibit 2).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="78f68e0d-ea10-4a56-b8ab-ddf2e87651b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="78f68e0d-ea10-4a56-b8ab-ddf2e87651b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Labor-force participation and unemployment data classify people of Chinese origin together with other Asians and group together Bangladeshis and Pakistanis.</span></span></span></a></span> For white workers, the combined participation rate for both sexes was 80 percent, followed by Indian workers, at 79 percent; for Black workers, it was 73 percent, and for Bangladeshis and Pakistanis, 62 percent. The overall gap between ethnic-minority individuals and white workers was 9.5 percentage points, down from 12.7 percent in 2004.</p>

<p>The gap is not very large between white men (84 percent) and ethnic-minority men (79 percent). The big difference is between white and ethnic-minority women, at 76 and 62 percent, respectively (Exhibit 3). The most extreme example is that of Pakistanis and Bangladeshis, where women accounted for 15 points of the 18-point labor-force participation gap. Age also plays a role. Ethnic-minority women in the youngest age bracketbetween 16 and 24 yearstrail furthest.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f0ec694-b1dd-48b0-9666-7bcd4e241709"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f0ec694-b1dd-48b0-9666-7bcd4e241709" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The exception is Pakistani and Bangladeshi women aged 50 and over. They have an even lower labor-force-participation rate, at 29 percent.</span></span></span></a></span> The average labor-force participation among ethnic-minority women in this group is 43 percent, compared with 63 percent for young white women.</p>

<p>For all groups, except white men and men of mixed ethnicity, labor-force-participation rates rose between 2004 and 2018.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dfbaec52-6136-4eff-b370-48e7d98d4571"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dfbaec52-6136-4eff-b370-48e7d98d4571" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">We focus on 200418 because these years are the longest, most recent period of comparison for which data exist.</span></span></span></a></span> White mens participation rate stayed flat at 84 percent between 2004 and 2018, while participation of ethnic-minority men rose from 75 to 79 percent. White women increased their participation from 71 to 76 percent, while that of BAME women rose even faster (55 to 62 percent). The most striking gains were among Bangladeshi and Pakistani women. While their participation in 2018 was still low (45 percent), that rate is 15 percentage points higher than in 2004. This increase in participation was followed by that of Indian women, whose participation rose from 64 to 72 percent, and Black women, with an increase from 63 to 69 percent.</p>
<p>Regarding unemployment, the story is similar. In 2018, all ethnic minorities except Indians had higher unemployment rates than white people (4 percent). Black workers had the highest unemployment rate (9 percent), followed by Pakistanis and Bangladeshis (8 percent). BAME women tended to suffer from slightly higher unemployment rates than men, but the differences were smaller than those for labor-force participation. The only substantial intragroup gender gap was between Bangladeshi and Pakistani men and women: male unemployment for these groups was 6 percent, less than half that of females (13 percent).</p>
<p>Differences in unemployment rates have narrowed over time. Unemployment has fallen at least three percentage points for all ethnic-minority groups since 2004 while remaining stable for white workers. The largest improvements were among Pakistanis and Bangladeshis (from 13 percent to 8 percent); mixed-ethnicity individuals (from 12 to 7 percent), and Black workers (from 13 to 9 percent).
To sum up, despite strong positive trends, labor-force participation and unemployment rates still show gaps relative to the white population, particularly among women.</p>
<h3>What kinds of jobs do Britains ethnic minorities do?</h3>
<p>Different ethnicities have varying distributions across occupational categories (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d2049636-939e-49bd-8542-3e433163fa27"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d2049636-939e-49bd-8542-3e433163fa27" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The source data are for the whole United Kingdom. The analysis has been conducted at a level for which the most granular reliable data are available. In this data set, people in employment are classified into 25 occupational categories and nine ethnic groups; significant variations can occur within specific categories.</span></span></span></a></span>  Chinese and Indians are likelier to work in the highest-paid occupations; they are overrepresented among corporate managers and directors, as well as in health occupations and among science, engineering, and technology professionals. For example, 13 percent of Indians are science, engineering, or tech professionals, more than double the share of the whole population (6 percent). White workers also are well represented in some highly paid occupations, and they have relatively more weight than Indians and Chinese in medium-pay jobs, including skilled construction and building trades and culture, media, and sports occupations. Ethnicities that are more likely than others to hold the lowest-paid occupations are Bangladeshi, Black, Pakistani, other Asian, and other ethnicity.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>These groups vary, however, in terms of the specific types of occupations in which they are overrepresented. Black workers are significantly overrepresented in caring personal-service occupations (almost 16 percent, compared with 7 percent for the whole population), and other Asians also are overrepresented here (9.5 percent). This occupational grouping includes jobs such as nursery nurses and home carers. Bangladeshis and those in the other-Asian and other-ethnicity groups are much more likely to work in textiles, printing, and other skilled trades, as well as to be drivers or operatives. Pakistanis are highly overrepresented among drivers and operatives.</p>
<p>In recent years, all groups have improved their occupational mix toward higher-paid jobs, and some ethnic minorities have been doing it at a faster pace than white workers. Between 2015 and March 2020, total employment in the United Kingdom increased from 30.5 million to 32.5 million jobs. The top five occupations in terms of median hourly pay grew by 19 percent, while the bottom five shrank by 1 percent. For the white population, total employment grew by 5 percent, while employment in the top five occupations increased 17 percent, and employment in the bottom five declined by 2 percent.</p>
<p>Indeed, the occupational mix for all ethnic-minority groups also shifted disproportionately toward the highest-paid occupations. Among Bangladeshis, for example, the number of employed individuals in the top five occupations grew 74 percent, while it shrank 2 percent for the bottom five. For those in the other-ethnicity group, the top five increase was 40 percent, and the bottom five decline was 5 percent.</p>
<p>Overall, then, when looking at differences in ethnic minorities occupational mix, there are two main distinctions. Indian and Chinese workers are likelier than other ethnic groups to be in higher-paid jobs, such as management or technology. All other minority groups are more likely than average to work in lower-paid occupations, such as personal care, administrative, and sales jobs.</p>
<h3>How do ethnic minorities compare in terms of pay?</h3>
<p>The unconditional pay gapthe difference in median hourly earnings between ethnic minorities and white workers, without controlling for factors like education and agefollows the expected pattern given the occupational data. Chinese and Indians had higher median hourly earnings than white workers in 2018, while all other groups had lower earnings, with Bangladeshis earning the least, 20 percent less than white employees.</p>
<p>The unconditional pay gap may also reflect existing skill differentials in the adult population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="273f5aad-5a79-45c3-a8db-5480ca0454eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="273f5aad-5a79-45c3-a8db-5480ca0454eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For adult skills, the breakdown is: Asian, Black, mixed ethnicity, other ethnicity, and white.</span></span></span></a></span> One factor is historical education outcomes. Some older ethnic-minority individuals will have grown up in another country with worse overall education or may have been disadvantaged in the United Kingdoms education system in the past. Another issue for ethnic minorities is access to coaching, training, and progression at work. Such opportunities tend to be more available to highly educated people, further polarizing the distribution of adult skills.</p>
<p>Moreover, within any given occupational group, some ethnicities are less likely to participate in training. For example, in a survey by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), 33 percent of all employees in caring, leisure, and personal-service occupations said they had participated in job-related training or education in the previous three months. Pakistani, Chinese, and Bangladeshi workers, however, were significantly less likely to have done so (25, 23, and 21 percent, respectively). Bangladeshis reported a lower-than-average rate of training in all nine occupational groups analyzed, and Chinese and Pakistanis in all but one.</p>
<p>While statistics on the level of adult skills by ethnicity are not abundant, the most recent data (2012) from the OECDs Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies, found that British adults from most ethnic minorities performed significantly worse than their white counterparts on tests of literacy, numeracy, and problem-solving skills.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="711aeeee-44a8-47c3-b377-e8349929c7b9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="711aeeee-44a8-47c3-b377-e8349929c7b9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The International Survey of Adult Skills 2012: Adult literacy, numeracy and problem solving skills in England,</em> Department for Business, Innovation and Skills, BIS Research Paper Number 139, October 2013, assets.publishing.service.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, for literacy, the average score for white people was 276, while the  scores of those of other ethnicity, Asians, and Black people were 254, 244, and 242, respectively.</p>
<p>A more sophisticated analysis of the pay gap tries to determine whether ethnic minorities earnings are lower even after controlling for other factors that can affect income; this is called the conditional pay gap. In 2019, researchers at the Bank of England adjusted earnings differences between ethnic groups using several relevant factors, including age, qualifications, occupation, and sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c3897db4-4d39-4d4f-a423-bdc8950d9be3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c3897db4-4d39-4d4f-a423-bdc8950d9be3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew G. Haldane, Zahid Amadxarif, Marilena Angeli, and Gabija Zemaityte, Understanding pay gaps, speech delivered by Haldane to the Joint Bank of England, Federal Reserve Bank, and European Central Bank Conference on Gender and Career Progression, Frankfurt, Germany, October 21, 2019, bankofengland.co.uk. The Bank of England uses the Oaxaca-Blinder decomposition technique and Goldins regression approach to explain pay gaps. See Claudia Goldin, A grand gender convergence: Its last chapter, <em>American Economic Review,</em> Volume 104, Number 4, April 2014, pp. 10911119.</span></span></span></a></span> The report found that when comparing people with very similar individual and job characteristics, ethnic-minority workers earned 10 percent less than white workers in the period 2014 to 2019. This was true for all ethnic groups, except for mixed ethnicity. Bangladeshis had the largest average conditional pay gap (20 percent), followed by Black workers, Pakistanis, and other Asians, all of them at 13 percent. For Indians and Chinese, the conditional gaps were 7 and 6 percent, respectively.</p>
<p>Another distinction to consider is between those born inside and outside the United Kingdom. The Bank of England and the ONS have found pay gaps to be substantially larger for foreign-born individuals. The Bank of England estimated the conditional pay gap at 5 percent for UK-born ethnic-minority individuals, compared with 12 percent for foreign-born ones. Possible factors include poorer childhood education, language barriers, lower levels of integration, and weaker employment networks.
Interestingly, unlike other labor-market metrics, the conditional ethnicity pay gap has not shrunk appreciably since 2000.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c2a769a3-523d-49b5-a92a-88bf0b7930c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c2a769a3-523d-49b5-a92a-88bf0b7930c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew G. <h2>How ethnic minorities are faring in education, health, and well-being</h2>
<p>As in the labor market, the overall picture for measures of education, health, and overall well-being is one of progressparticularly when it comes to educationbut with some troubling gaps.</p>
<h3>BAME educational performance</h3>
<p>What stands out in educational attainment is the generally strong and improving performance of ethnic minorities. This is likely to be one of the reasons for the progress they have made in the
labor market.</p>
<p>Most ethnic-minority groups do comparatively well at school from a young age. At six to seven years old, math scores were higher for Chinese, Indians, and other Asians than for white students, while Bangladeshis and mixed-ethnicity pupils were close.  Regarding writing, all ethnic minorities except Pakistanis and the other-ethnicity group had higher scores than white students. In reading, all BAME groups scored higher than white students, except for Bangladeshis, who did as well as white students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5fff390b-b412-4269-bf4d-338298bc9612"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5fff390b-b412-4269-bf4d-338298bc9612" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Education, skills and training, Ethnicity facts and figures, Race Disparity Unit, gov.uk; https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/race-disparity-unit.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The scores are particularly striking when broken down by household income.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c4ee0388-f3c9-4de0-bdb7-44cdedde6438"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span <p>Similar patterns show up in Attainment 8 scores,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f709e73b-1632-4e58-95a1-e3ce5828cb63"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f709e73b-1632-4e58-95a1-e3ce5828cb63" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Attainment 8 is a measure of a pupils average grade across eight subjects in the General Certificate of Secondary Education (GCSE) exams.</span></span></span></a></span> which refer to exams students typically take when they are 14 to 16 years old (Exhibit 5). Girls scored higher than boys across ethnicities and income groups.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f5989ab3-70fc-4530-bd7c-0975e7a9e217"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f5989ab3-70fc-4530-bd7c-0975e7a9e217" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The patterns are similar when using the Progress 8 metric, which measures the improvement in pupils attainment at age 15 relative to a comparison group at ages seven to 11.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>As for higher education, entry rates for everyone increased between 2006 and 2018, and students from all ethnic-minority groups are now more likely than white students to enter higher education.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="840ba419-b509-423d-b23b-7fa4feb21862"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="840ba419-b509-423d-b23b-7fa4feb21862" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The data considered only students from state schools; see Entry rates into higher education, Ethnicity facts and figures, Race Disparity Unit, updated August 24, 2020, gov.uk. The breakdown is Black, Chinese, mixed ethnicity, other Asian, other ethnicity, and white.</span></span></span></a></span> Chinese students were the most likely to do so (66 percent). The recent performance of Black students is particularly striking. In 2006, they were the least likely group to attend university (22 percent); in 2018, at 41 percent, they were third.</p>
<p>The news is not all good. For example, Black students were significantly more likely to drop out of university than white ones in 2015,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91da1b1d-d1af-48a0-be84-b311390a4bfa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91da1b1d-d1af-48a0-be84-b311390a4bfa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>On course for success? Student retention at university,</em> Social Market Foundation, July 2017, smf.co.uk. Retention statistics are due to be updated but were not available at the time of writing.</span></span></span></a></span> and undergraduate grades earned by all ethnic minorities were lower than those of white students. Almost one in three white graduates obtained first-class degrees, but only one in five ethnic-minority graduates did so in 2018.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="091339ba-b408-426d-b868-eea5ec41640f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="091339ba-b408-426d-b868-eea5ec41640f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For undergraduate grades, the breakdown is Asian, Black, mixed ethnicity, other ethnicity, and white.</span></span></span></a></span> There is no single explanation for these discrepancies, which exist regardless of students prior attainment at A-level. However, recent surveys point to, among other things, lack of diversity and role models among senior university staff, as well as institutional and cultural barriers that may disadvantage ethnic-minority students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="51b44dd1-a6db-4327-b6a3-74ab496e7a93"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="51b44dd1-a6db-4327-b6a3-74ab496e7a93" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Black, Asian and minority ethnic student attainment at UK universities: #ClosingtheGap,</em> Universities UK, May 2019, universitiesuk.ac.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>A study published in 2018 also found that employment rates for all BAME groups six months after graduation were substantially lower than for white graduates, and earnings were slightly lower for some. Local area characteristics could account for some of these differences: with the exception of London, ethnic minorities are more likely to live in less prosperous regions, where job opportunities for graduates are fewer.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ca5e2123-0654-49c8-b50c-7bc119db3535"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ca5e2123-0654-49c8-b50c-7bc119db3535" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Wouter Zwysen and Simonetta Longhi, Employment and earning differences in the early career of ethnic-minority British graduates: The importance of university career, parental background and area characteristics, <em>Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies,</em> Volume 44, Number 1, 2018,  doi:10.1080/1369183X.2017.1338559.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<h3>Health outcomes and Britains ethnic minorities</h3>
<p>Ethnic minorities have worse health outcomes than white people on many metrics, and there are significant variations among minority groups. In 2017, the white population had the lowest rate of infant mortality (3.1 deaths per 1,000 live births); Pakistanis had the highest (7.3).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b99661be-5c44-4ca2-bda6-f89c4521ea91"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b99661be-5c44-4ca2-bda6-f89c4521ea91" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For infant mortality, the breakdown is Bangladeshi, Black, Indian, Pakistani, other ethnicity, and white.</span></span></span></a></span> Infant mortality actually increased among Bangladeshis (from 4.7 in 2006 to 5.6 in 2017) and Indians (from 4.1 to 4.7). However, it decreased among Black infants, falling from 8.0 to 6.8.</p>
<p>Another important health factor is obesity. In 2018, 74 percent of Black adults were overweight or obese; that rate is 11 percentage points more than for white adults, who were the second-most-overweight ethnicity, and almost 40 percentage points more than the Chinese, the least overweight of the groups. These patterns have remained largely consistent since 2015.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL <p>Compared with white individuals, members of most ethnic-minority groups report higher prevalence of long-term conditions such as chest, breathing, heart, blood pressure, or circulation problems. This is true regardless of age, but particularly so among those at least 40 years old.  Bangladeshis, Black adults, Chinese, Indians, Pakistanis, and other-Asians in this age cohort were more likely than white adults to report these conditions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7c72b7f3-00a1-42b4-a481-3fbcf2a420eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7c72b7f3-00a1-42b4-a481-3fbcf2a420eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">ONS Annual Population Survey, April 2019March 2020. <p>Eating habits and physical exercise are relevant determinants of health outcomes. On average, white adults reported the healthiest eating habits, while Black adults had the unhealthiest ones.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d29f49a-145f-4bef-960f-b43d805132b6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d29f49a-145f-4bef-960f-b43d805132b6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on the number of portions of fruit and vegetables respondents reported eating each day.     </span></span></span></a></span> Physical activity shows a similar pattern: Asians (excluding Chinese), Black people, and those of other ethnicity were less active. This holds to a large extent regardless of occupational status, indicating that this pattern is unlikely to be explained simply by income or education.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2926e252-e5b7-4f65-a0f5-31f354eb8081"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2926e252-e5b7-4f65-a0f5-31f354eb8081" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Physical activity, Ethnicity facts and figures, Race Disparity Unit, updated April 27, 2020, service.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

areas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" assets.publishing.service.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/public-sector/how-we-help-clients">Public & Social Sector Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<h3>Well-being measures and life satisfaction</h3>
<p>Mental and physical health, along with job satisfaction and social relationships, are important determinants of life satisfaction. The generally worse physical health among ethnic minorities could help explain why their average well-beingmost frequently measured by self-reported life satisfactiontends to be somewhat lower than that of white people.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3610fbe2-791d-4e6e-814e-c67722a25734"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3610fbe2-791d-4e6e-814e-c67722a25734" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Analysis of mental health was outside the scope of this report.</span></span></span></a></span> In 2018, there were no ethnic minorities that reported higher levels of well-being than white people; but Bangladeshis, Black people, and those of mixed and other ethnicity reported statistically significantly lower levels of life satisfaction.</p>
<p>However, the trends in life satisfaction and other well-being metrics are positive. Self-reported well-being increased between 2012 and 2018 among all ethnicities and across all four metrics tracked by the ONS: life satisfaction, happiness, feeling worthwhile, and (lack of) anxiety. Moreover, the increase in well-being for individuals in most minority groups has been occurring at a faster pace than for white individuals, so the gap has been closing.</p>
<p>For example, in 2012, the average score for life satisfaction among the white population was 7.5, higher than for all ethnic minority groups except Asian other, Chinese, and Indians. Black individuals reported the lowest life-satisfaction score in 2012 (6.8). In 2018, the score for white individuals had increased to 7.7, and only four BAME groups remained significantly<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dd09f457-8576-4b32-b225-52a36c09ca5b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dd09f457-8576-4b32-b225-52a36c09ca5b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Statistically significant difference at the 95 percent confidence level. A 0.1-point difference in life satisfaction is roughly equivalent to a 70 percent difference in household income at the individual level, all other things equal. See, for example, Paul Frijters et al, <em>A happy choice: Wellbeing as the goal of government,</em> Centre for Economic Performance, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> less satisfied with their livesBlack individuals (7.3), mixed-ethnicity (7.4), Bangladeshis (7.5), and those of other ethnicity (7.5).</p>
<p>On anxiety, in 2012, white individuals recorded the lowest score (3.0), while all ethnic minorities except the Chinese reported higher anxiety, ranging from the least-anxious Black individuals (3.2) to those of mixed ethnicity (3.5). By 2018, white individuals had reduced their average anxiety levels (to 2.9), but so had everyone else, and by more.</p>
<p>The findings on ethnic minorities relative outcomes in education, health, and well-being are important in at least in two ways. First, improving themand reducing any gapsis positive in and of itself. Second, they are crucial because they affect peoples ability to prosper. Better-educated, healthier, and happier individuals are also more productive, which increases their chances to engage positively with the labor market, economy, and society.</p>
<h2>How COVID-19 is affecting BAME lives and livelihoods</h2>
<p>The socioeconomic metrics we have consideredeconomic, educational, health, and well-beingare all under pressure from COVID-19, which has proved particularly challenging for ethnic minorities. They are more likely to die from the virus, be exposed to it at work, and to work in occupations hard hit by job losses and furloughs.</p>
<h3>COVID-19 and ethnic minorities</h3>
<p>After accounting for age, members of every ethnic- minority group in Britain are likelier than white people to die from COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="145be186-849a-4355-a962-e90eabd6a18c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="145be186-849a-4355-a962-e90eabd6a18c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Coronavirus (COVID-19) related deaths by ethnic group, England and Wales: 2 March 2020 to 15 May 2020, Office for National Statistics, updated June 19, 2020, ons.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> For Black men (who have triple the white death rate) and Black women (more than 2.5 times), the difference is particularly stark. Bangladeshis and Pakistanis have the next-highest death rate (more than twice the death rate of the white population), while Chinese and mixed-ethnicity women have the lowest (5 percent and 33 percent more likely to die from COVID-19 than the white population, respectively). These differences partly reflect the patterns in health described in the previous section; many BAME groups have a higher prevalence of preexisting conditions that make COVID-19 more deadly, such as obesity and diabetes among Black adults and cardiovascular disease among Pakistani men.</p>
<p>Britains ethnic minorities are also more likely to live in densely populated areas or in overcrowded households, which makes them more prone to contagion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c244b806-4822-47c5-9e09-305536c83cec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c244b806-4822-47c5-9e09-305536c83cec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Overcrowded households, Ethnicity facts and figures, September 9, 2020, service.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> Occupational and socioeconomic status also play a role. Except for Chinese and Indian ethnicities, BAME groups tend to be overrepresented in occupations that require proximity to colleagues, customers, or members of the public. This may make them more likely to contract the disease. Some ethnic-minority groups are also more exposed to the virus at work: for example, 27 percent of Black workers are employed in the healthcare sector, compared with 14 percent of all workers.</p>
<p>The COVID-19 crisis does not affect all occupations and sectors equally: <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-in-the-united-kingdom-assessing-jobs-at-risk-and-the-impact-on-people-and-places">some jobs are more at risk than others</a>. Jobs dependent on overseas tourism, for example, are more likely to be hurting than those in the package-delivery or health fields. Therefore, the distribution of jobs among different population groups is an important factor in COVID-19-related job losses or furloughs. Occupational patterns are especially significant because, in the United Kingdom, most of the short-term adjustment has taken the form of furloughs, in which people remain officially employed, making the unemployment rate a poor representation of COVID-19s impact on the labor market.</p>
<p>Although we lack detailed information by ethnicity on who has been furloughed, two other variables offer a broad sense of how ethnic minorities have fared. One is the physical proximity required to do a job; the other is the percentage of workers who have been furloughed in a given sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="70d8a7bd-1e33-4743-8b2f-32c4890856da"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="70d8a7bd-1e33-4743-8b2f-32c4890856da" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The data on both proximity by occupation and furloughs by sector come from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). For proximity, Which occupations have the highest potential exposure to the coronavirus (COVID-19)?, ONS, May 11, 2020, ons.gov.uk. For furloughs, we use ONS data on the average proportion of furloughed employees by sector between April 6 and July 12, 2020, from the Business Impact of COVID-19 survey. Business Impact of COVID-19 Survey (BICS) results, ONS, ons.gov.uk. Data about furloughs do not exist for all sectors, but the ones for which data exist cover 85 percent of total employment.</span></span></span></a></span> To the extent that an ethnic group is overrepresented in an occupation that requires close physical proximity or in a sector with a high level of furloughs, its members jobs are more likely to be vulnerable due to COVID-19.</p>
<p>The logic is that people in jobs that require high physical proximity to other individuals will not have been able to work during lockdowns and will likely be slow to return to normal work while physical-distancing requirements stay in place. (There are exceptions to this principle, such as essential workers in healthcare and transport.) Similarly, workers in sectors that have suffered a larger proportion of furloughs have experienced the impact of COVID-19 more severely, and are likely to continue to do so.</p>
<p>According to <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-in-the-united-kingdom-assessing-jobs-at-risk-and-the-impact-on-people-and-places">McKinsey research</a> published in May, people belonging to a minority ethnic group were on average only slightly more exposed than white people to job losses or furloughs due to the pandemic. But when specific ethnic groups are considered, bigger differences emerge.</p>
<p>Some groups are overrepresented in high-proximity occupations and hence are more likely to suffer because of COVID-19 (Exhibit 6). Bangladeshis and those in the other-ethnicity group appear to be most vulnerable to COVID-19-related job losses or furloughs. One reason is that Bangladeshis and other-ethnicity individuals are likelier than others to be in occupations related to textiles, printing, and skilled trades (think tailors, printers, butchers, and chefs). Bangladeshis are more likely to be in sales occupations, such as retail assistants or cashiers. These two ethnic groups are also overrepresented in transport-related occupations.</p>

<p>The same two groups are also overrepresented in some economic sectors with high rates of furloughs and underrepresented in some low-furlough sectors (Exhibit 7). Bangladeshis and individuals in the other-ethnicity group are more likely than average to work in accommodation and food services, which furloughed 70 percent of their workers in the second quarter of 2020. Conversely, Bangladeshis are underrepresented in healthcare, and those of other-ethnicity are underrepresented in education. These two sectors generally require close proximity but had relatively low furlough rates (7 and 10 percent, respectively), because many of their personnel are classified as essential workers.</p>

<p>Pakistanis, Bangladeshis, and other-ethnicity individuals also have higher-than-average rates of self-employment, while all other ethnic groups have lower rates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5ffc4c43-526d-4529-b4f1-32768cab9e00"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5ffc4c43-526d-4529-b4f1-32768cab9e00" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Coronavirus and self-employment in the UK, Office for National Statistics, April 2020, ons.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> COVID-19 appears to have hit the self-employed particularly hard: the self-employed account for 22 percent of job-support claims, higher than their share of the workforce (15 percent). It doesnt help that, according to the National Federation of Self-Employed & Small Businesses, ethnic-minority-owned small businesses are more likely to be in less affluent areas and to be in sectors, such as hospitality and transport, that have been particularly challenged by COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="523a580b-f641-4bc5-9321-83dfe0212537"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="523a580b-f641-4bc5-9321-83dfe0212537" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">National Federation of Self-Employed & Small Businesses, fsb.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Black people stand out for their high representation in caring personal services (15.6 percent, or more than twice the national average) and health professionals (8.9 percent, versus 4.8 percent for all ethnicities). These jobs require close physical proximity but are mostly in health and social care, the sector with the lowest rate of furloughs. Consequently, the health risks are greater, but the unemployment risks are relatively low.</p>
<p>Like Black individuals, Chinese ones face mixed employment prospects, but for the opposite reasons. On average, Chinese workers are highly concentrated in occupations that require low proximity, putting them at lower risk of COVID-19-related job losses. However, they also have a high percentage of jobs (16.7 percent) in the high-furlough accommodation and food-services sector and are less likely than average to work in low-furlough sectors like health care and education.</p>
<p>The evidence suggests that Indian workers are the least vulnerable to COVID-19s impact on jobs. Indians have high representation in low-proximity occupations, such as those associated with science and technology. Moreover, they are more likely than average to work in low-furlough sectors such as information and communication (12 percent furlough rate), while they are underrepresented in high-furlough sectors, such as accommodation and food services and arts, entertainment, and recreation
(70 percent for each) or construction (33 percent).</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Pakistanis, Bangladeshis, and other-ethnicity individuals have higher-than-average rates of self-employment, while all other ethnic groups have lower rates.</p></blockquote></div>
<h3>Coping with COVID-19</h3>
<p>Ethnic minorities on the whole are more vulnerable than white people to other forms of economic distress. Take household savings, which are crucial not only to cover basic needs when income falls but also to provide long-term opportunity. According to the Institute for Fiscal Studies, about 30 percent of white and Indian households can cover six months of income with savings; for Pakistanis, the figure is less than 20 percent, and for Bangladeshis and Black households, less than 10 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5ae7371a-9155-4cdd-b15c-a944a28b3042"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5ae7371a-9155-4cdd-b15c-a944a28b3042" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Are some ethnic groups more vulnerable?</em> May 2020, Figure 20. The source does not report separate data for Chinese and those in the mixed-ethnicity, other-Asian, and other-ethnicity groups.</span></span></span></a></span> Runnymede, an independent think tank, found a similar pattern when it came to wealth.
White British households had, on average, the most wealth (282,000), and Indians were next. Then, however, the drop-off was steep: Pakistanis held less than half this value of assets, Black households of Caribbean descent 89,000, and Bangladeshis and Black households of African descent less than 30,000.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ead93d67-6e07-4a4c-8bea-57b89b99ebaa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ead93d67-6e07-4a4c-8bea-57b89b99ebaa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Omar Khan, <em>The colour of money: How racial inequalities obstruct a fair and resilient economy,</em> Runnymede, April 2020, runnymedetrust.org, Figure 5. The data group Chinese with other Asians, and mixed-ethnicity and other-ethnicity groups.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Another relevant issue is household type. Single-person households are more vulnerable than others to economic shocks because, in the case of income loss, no one else is there to pick up the slack. As for households with dependent children, if parents have economic or health difficulties, these can limit the childrens opportunities. The loss of a parents income, for example, may cause the family to not send its children to university.</p>
<p>According to the 2011 census,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f9a9dfb8-152b-45d2-9614-3e3453a01a22"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f9a9dfb8-152b-45d2-9614-3e3453a01a22" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These patterns may have changed since 2011, but household type is a slow-moving statistic, so we expect the direction of large differences across ethnicities to be broadly consistent.</span></span></span></a></span> Black and mixed-ethnicity individuals were significantly more likely to live in one-adult households, while Bangladeshis and Pakistanis were the most likely to be raising dependent children. The combination of these characteristicssingle adults raising dependent childrenis most common among Black and mixed-ethnicity individuals and least common among Chinese and Indians. Considering that 86 percent of single parents are women<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ce0f277b-f0ef-4630-95b4-8f3bef3d8ba6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ce0f277b-f0ef-4630-95b4-8f3bef3d8ba6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Families and households in the UK: 2019,</em> Office for National Statistics, November 2019, ons.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> and that the employment gap is larger for ethnic-minority females, the implication is that ethnic-minority lone mothers could be particularly vulnerable to COVID-19-related economic difficulties.</p>
<p>Household overcrowding is another factor to consider, for two reasons. First, living in overcrowded conditions likely increases the chances of contagion. And second, it can exacerbate other difficulties associated with COVID-19, such as mental illness and learning gaps, particularly in times of confinement or semiconfinement. When schools are partially or fully closed, an overcrowded household can create stress and a <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-student-learning-in-the-united-states-the-hurt-could-last-a-lifetime">less favorable environment for students</a>. According to government data, only 2 percent of white people live in overcrowded households, compared with 24 percent of Bangladeshis, 18 percent of Pakistanis, and 16 percent of Blacks of African descent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2acb7599-6194-43d3-b787-b5ffacdbe292"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2acb7599-6194-43d3-b787-b5ffacdbe292" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Overcrowded households, Ethnicity facts and figures, September 9, 2020, service.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>How automation and workplace transformations could affect ethnic minorities</h2>
<p>Workforce transitions are an economic constant; they are necessary for countries continued development. But they are not painless. <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/inequality-a-persisting-challenge-and-its-implications">Previous work by McKinsey shows</a> that, in general, automation and other trends that are transforming workplaces around the world also tend to create further inequalities. For example, the demand for workers is shifting away from lower-skilled routine and manual jobs to those requiring higher levels of education and more sophisticated cognitive, technological, and social and emotional skills.</p>
<p>What does this mean for Britains ethnic minorities? Again, the picture is not uniform.</p>
<p>Based on research analyzing which occupations are likely to be automated and what type of work is likely to be in high demand in the future, some of Britains most disadvantaged ethnic minorities could face big challenges. That is because there is a substantial overlap between occupations that have been hurt by COVID-19 and those that were already expected to face difficult employment prospects by 2030and some BAME groups are concentrated in these jobs. Moreover, COVID-19 could <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-covid-19-recovery-will-be-digital-a-plan-for-the-first-90-days">accelerate</a> automation, especially if employing people continues to be cumbersome or costly due to physical distancing.</p>
<p>We base our employment and automation projections on pre-COVID-19 <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/jobs-lost-jobs-gained-what-the-future-of-work-will-mean-for-jobs-skills-and-wages">research from the McKinsey Global Institute</a>. Exhibit 8 combines the findings on the degree of employment impact that COVID-19 is having with the estimated automation potential by ethnicity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2038cdf3-4d0e-4c7e-b9a4-61241ee1fcfa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2038cdf3-4d0e-4c7e-b9a4-61241ee1fcfa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">We have calculated the COVID-19 employment-vulnerability index shown in Exhibit 8 based on the data in Exhibits 6 and 7. The index was weighted to give 75 percent weight to sectors and 25 percent weight to occupations. More weight was given to sectors because a significant proportion of high-proximity occupationssuch as those in healthcare, social care, and policinghave not been furloughed despite their high proximity. Automation potential refers to the percent of hours worked in each occupation that could be automated by adapting currently demonstrated technology. It is based on a McKinsey Global Institute analysis of 2,000 tasks across 800 US occupations; these have then been translated into UK occupations.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 8</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/problems%20amid%20progress%20improving%20lives%20and%20livelihoods%20for%20ethnic%20minorities%20in%20the%20united%20kingdom/svgz-covid-ukethnicity-ex8.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Indians employment prospects appear less vulnerable to both COVID-19 effects and automation as compared with other ethnicities employment prospects." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/problems%20amid%20progress%20improving%20lives%20and%20livelihoods%20for%20ethnic%20minorities%20in%20the%20united%20kingdom/svgz-covid-ukethnicity-ex8.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Bangladeshis and other-ethnicity individuals appear not only to be among the groups hurting most from COVID-19 but also to be overrepresented in occupations that are likelier to face reduced employment in the period to 2030, such as in textiles, printing, and other skilled trades. Bangladeshis and Pakistanis are also more likely than average to work in sales and customer-service occupations, which are relatively vulnerable to automation. On the other hand, these three ethnic groups are underrepresented in science, research, engineering and technology related-occupations, as well as in business, media, and public-service professions, where automation potential is much lower.</p>
<p>For Black workers, the picture is mixed. On the one hand, a relatively large proportion of Black individuals work in health and social care and other caring service occupations, such as nursery nurses and home carers. Due to the nonroutine nature of these roles and the importance of social and emotional skills, they are less likely to be automated than other jobs. Workers in these occupations are also among the most likely to participate in job-related training, so their skills are less likely to become obsolete. On the other hand, Black workers hold highly automatable jobs more often than average, such as roles in skilled trades and administrative services.</p>
<p>At the other end of the spectrum, Indians appear to have an easier path ahead given their above-average likelihood of working in health, research, and science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fieldsoccupations characterized by limited automation potential and substantial future demand growth. Based on their current occupational mix, Chinese workers also are well placed for future employment growth, with their strong position in STEM occupations and above-average likelihood of holding business, media, and public-service professional jobs.</p>
<p>It is important to note that these observations refer to averages for entire ethnic groups. There are large differences between the most and least at-risk individuals within each group. For example, approximately 20 percent of Chinese employees are in occupations, such as administrative roles or skilled trades, where 40 to 60 percent of the hours worked today could be automated by adapting currently demonstrated technology.</p>
<p>Overall, the outlook is troubling. The most disadvantaged ethnic minoritiesBangladeshis, other-ethnicity individuals, and Pakistanisare the most likely to suffer negative labor-market consequences from both COVID-19 and future automation.</p>
